segments.text: Test, test, test, test, test.
Just don't even think it's here.
Just there.
Why don't you start now?
Okay.
This is part of the river collection here in this room.
I do have a few other books scattered throughout.
My goal is to collect every edition of everything.
So these, pardon me, but what I'm looking at here in our subsequent editions, they're not... Well, there are a couple of these, but most of them are...
For instance, I think it's this one, at random, Powder River, Shethersburg.
This was the first part.
Powder River, the W-D-E-R.
Letterbuck by Struthers, S-C-R-U-T-O-G-R, S-B-E-R-T.
There's a very well-known Western writer.
This was published in 1938.
It was, I believe, the
or the fourth book in the series.
It's beautiful condition.
I see condition is exceedingly important to you.
I try to collect books in very good or better condition.
Occasionally with the reprints, in order to document the books, I have to take whatever I can get.
As the print ones, as the books were printed, some of the print ones were very small.
Could you give me a little background, explain what the series is?
The series consists of 65 titles.
It was a series of plans, started by Clemston, who was a
There she is.
Constance is incredible.
It's a little biography of her that was prepared by the Women's National Book Association.
In 1980, they have a little fire of her personal recollections by friends of Skinner, and they do give the Constance of Skinner Award.

beginning in 1940, the year after her death. They give the Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston Winston
I think I'll be able to get the background on her.
What prompted her fascination for Rivers, I wonder.
I wanted to get to her a copy of the... That's great.
And this is Jane talking.
What I want to say about Nancy Skinner is that she wrote a wonderful essay which outlined her intentions.
intentions with the Rivers of America series.
It's very, very cleverly thought through that America developed along its rivers and that for a long time the rivers were the major means of transportation, getting from one place to the other.
You have only to think about Lewis and Clark, for example.
But there were no highways, there were no railroads, there were no airlines, there were no bus routes.
You either went by wagon and took six months to get from St.
Louis to Maine
in Salt Lake City, or you use the rivers.
And she said that the story of our country, and she was a Canadian, I've heard, should be told through its rivers, and it should be told by poets and writers, not just historians.
This is so important to this new book that I'm working on.
She said incredible, incredible vision, really.
She wrote this?
This is written?
Yes.
Is this something I can take?
I can make a copy.
Oh, good.
We have a copy.
Excuse me.
How do you take a copy?
Just black.
All right.
Carol?
Green?
This was the essay that set forth the series, The River of America.
This was taken from the New York Public Library.
They have a 1937 question mark.
My research has determined now, after finding her papers at the New York Public Library, that this was probably written in 1935.
She talks about giving the brochure for prospective writers.
And this was her first essay.
Rivers at American Folk, O-L-K, by Constance Lindsay, L-I-N-D-S-A-Y, Skinner.
And it starts off, when Americans told her troubles that do not end quickly, such as the depression now passing off,
They begin presently to examine their own sources of the nation and their own story of the people.
They forget about these in good times.
And she goes on.
And she talks about, this is to be a literary and not an historical series.
The authors of these books will be novelists and poets.
That's wonderful.
On them, now in America, as in all lands and times, rests the real responsibility of interpretation.
She didn't want, in fact,
If you are able to attend the symposium, Dr. Thomas B. Clark, who wrote the Kentucky, and he's a noted Kentucky historian, he's in his 90s now.
He wanted to write.
He wanted to write a book on the Kentucky.
She turned him down because she didn't want historians to write that book.
After she died unexpectedly in 1939, after only two years of
Oh really?
So she really didn't see it?
She saw five titles published and she died while editing the gallery of the Hudson.
Significant been her first choice.
The choice for the writer of the first book was a poet, more than anything else.
And the poet was?
Robert T. Tristram Coffin.
Could we spell it?
It's Robert P. Tristram.
Okay.
And what was the river that he did?
Oh, the upper name?
Yeah.
And this was the first book in the series.
His reputation really was the Bentecost and the Dramatons.
They're a famous Maine family.
I went to Bates up in Maine.
You did.
I went to Germany.
They did?
Yeah.
I didn't graduate from Germany, but I was a big old.
So we were kind of cousins.
They did, and they still do.
Okay, great.
This was the first.
And this is inscribed?
Yeah.
It's Kennebec.
He may have taught us things sometimes.
He taught us those.
Oh, it's, Coffin is a famous, famous main name.
Frank Coffin was a federal judge.
The first book, they do lay out.
So they even had a little R of a... This is a series device that Farr and Reinhardt used.

Farr and Reinhardt published his book until 1945, and beginning in January of 1946, Reinhardt and company was formed, and they devised their own series device, which was a stylized oval with a little steamship in the center.
But this was...
I think Spires, and I forget who... Yeah, we have the name of the firm that just designed the logo.
Here's your copy.
Great, thank you, sir.
This may have a little more body than you like.
No, no, I like it.
Actually, it's wonderful.
Good.
I require caffeine, actually.
I do, too.
Well, this is what started it.
Why don't you... I'll join you.
Get comfortable somewhere.
You're looking... Standing up.
Would you rather sit down?
Would you rather have a chair in front of the bookcase?
Sit in a nice, comfortable chair.
Want me to bring your pocket, Carol?
Why don't I sit over here, Carol?
And...
How about if I sit right here?
How's this?
Okay.
The books are fine.
The books can stay right where they are.
Okay.
Okay.
for the past six years, and I have original correspondence.
Many of the people with whom I have corresponded have since died, so I have information that really would have been lost forever had I not... Wow.
Maybe if we could talk just for both of you, 15 or 20 minutes, just to like and get, to just sit someplace close to me.
And I think you keep mentioning things that are...
You talk about the correspondence with the authors, and all these things are fascinating.
So tell me a little bit.
Why don't I start at the beginning?
Really.
I'm going to start right.
And then that will occasion some questions.
All right.
This started back in 1986.
Gene, you may know.
had donated a large collection of federal writer's projects and WPA items to our local library.
In 1984 and 1986, we had a symposium sponsored by the Florida Center for the Books and the Library of Congress here in Fort Lauderdale announcing these donations.
And there were several authors, and Jerry Manjohn, who directed the project, were here in town.
Two or three days.
That was the same weekend of the Miami Book Fair.
So with our good friend, Bill Pail, who was a book dealer in Georgetown and had a great jeans collection, we went to Miami and were going through the booze.
And I picked up a book on the St.
Johns River.
And it was in
pretty good shape, a dust jacket, and my sister lives on the St.
John's in Jacksonville, and I said, this will make a nice Christmas gift for her.
It was November.
From the year, once again?
I thought you said that, okay.
So, Bill Hale, the book dealer, said that would make a nice collection.
And, of course, Gene had just, we had just gotten rid of, I don't know, seven or eight hundred thousand pieces and books.
How many?
I don't know.
I think it was
We've lost count, but it was close to a thousand.
They were not all books.
But it was mostly books.
The Federal Writers Project went on for a long time, and they produced a lot of things because they were all over.
Stuff that was being read all over the United States, little monographs, little broadsheets, books and the state guides and all that.
There's a fellow in my book, before I forget, Fred
Mr. Bride, I guess is his name.
I will look it up before, but he collects these by the way of his project.
There are several famous collections.
There's a doctor in Philadelphia, as I remember.
There's a collector with an oriental name.
But immodestly, I will tell you, at the time of the donation to our library, my collection was the finest and the largest.
And it really got the library off on a new tack altogether.
Depression era studies and
And John Cole was here for that.
Yeah, I'm here.
That's when we met him.
So you actually had the collecting impulse.
Did it precede your own personal passion?
I think a little.
I think we all have a little desire to collect in us.
We were married the year that I made that donation, and I had been collecting federal artists 20 years before that long term.
Really?
Yeah.
I've had the impulse.
Mine was inspired by a Washington, D.C.
guy, which is still a very good guy for the city.
Did you have all of it?
Did you manage to get the whole?
Well, I had all the state guys and all the city guys, but no one will ever know what all really means in reference to the Federal Writers Project, because they gave their support to maybe a woman.
That's exactly the volunteer art department.
They did a cookbook or something.
Oh, they did a lot of cookbooks.
A lot of cookbooks.
And our library has continued to buy WPA and Federal Writers Project materials, and they have, I understand, doubled what Jane has given us just through the perseverance of working with dealers.
And people know that we will buy, our library will buy these items as some are available.
It is important, why did you decide to carpet it?
Did you feel that it was kind of complete, or was it time to pass it on?
I don't remember ever selling anything as much as I do, as all book collectors do.
I've done a few trades here.
The motivating force, however, was Jean Trevi.
Jean called me one day sort of out of the blue and asked me if I'd have lunch with her.
I was too innocent to realize that she had her eye on my collection, but that's what it was.
She was quite frank about it at the luncheon.
She's a frank lady.
Plus, yes, I had it.
And when I was a kid, I collected keys.
I used to go to, remember now, we're talking about depression era.
I would go into a key shop and say, do you have any keys that I can have?
Have you got any players?
Have you got any old?
Often they'd give me a cigar box.
And 10, 15 pounds of keys.
Here's a question for you.
Do you still have the keys?
No.
And I'll give you a better question.
Where are they?
I have no idea.
How did I come to party?
Blame your mother.
She must have thrown them by.
Well, there might have been... Well, I was born the mother.
Well, I went through a series of... How shall I put it?
I've been married before.
And maybe the keys got... Probably when I joined the Navy, I sort of got rid of a lot of... Here's another question.
I bet you'd like to have them back.
No, I would, because I never got to the logical point of learning locks, how to build a lock.
I know how locks work, but I never went through that.
The next thing you have to collect keys, it's got to be locks, right?
And I never got to that stage.
But again, don't blame Mother Glenn.
When we're dead, I'll give you a Hitler line, which is going to be used in the new book.
Okay, so we have this as background.
That's right.
That's how it began.
I bought the book and sat on the shelf here in the living room for maybe, I didn't give it to my sister for Christmas.
I just really didn't part.
It's a collector for you all the way.
There it is.
And shortly after, maybe in the spring, maybe the next fall.
Now we're into 87?
So this collection has been put together in fewer than 10 years.
That's very important.
We were in San Francisco.
She was at a conference.
I had some time to kill, and I wanted into a rare bookstore.
And I, by the chance, do you have any Rivers of America titles?
And the woman looked at me, and she said, no.
She said, I specialize in children's literature.
I haven't given much thought.
And then all of a sudden, she said, yes, I do have a couple.

She said that I have them cataloged by the illustrator, and she had a copy of, a pristine copy of Brandywine by Henry Stiles Candy, which was illustrated by Andrew Wyatt, and the Arkansas... I knew you were going to say that because that's where they are, down in the Brandywine.
Illustrated by Donald McKay, who was a well-known children's book illustrator back in the 30s.
So I bought the book.
and one was $65, I think one was $25.
Steel.
Anything Wyeth.
And it was his first book to illustrate, ever.
We learned recently, last September at Wyeth in Nashville, Tennessee, that that was his first book of inspiration.
He was 23 years old.
And I love N.C.
Wyeth better than...
Better than Andrew, more than Jamie, I think.
Well, this was Andrew Wyatt.
This was Andrew?
Uh-huh.
He was 23?
Andrew, this would have been in 1940.
I'm sorry, I thought you said that.
Okay, it's still a steal.
Okay, it's still a steal.
And he's still wonderful.
So then I had three.
Now you have three.
And I have three.
And in these books, and this one's too early.
I remember that day in San Francisco.
Do you remember the name of the bookstore?
Yes, the Montsutter Street Bookstall.
Check it out.
So, they've moved their location, but it was the bookstall.
Now, this is the way, this is what I had.
I had this book, Rivers of America Books Already Published Art, and it started in chronological order.
I still had no way of knowing how many titles were in the series.
I didn't know what I was looking for, in other words.
I went to the library, books in print, to see books in series, to see if there was a list of release of America series books.
Well, there was, but it's very confusing.
Some, they list it out of print, and I guess if they're not in print, you might get some bad information.
I've had more bad information from books in libraries than I want to remember.
It had me going in the wrong direction early on my collecting date.
But anyway, I started aggressively collecting the books.
I took the ad out of the New York Times for rare and out-of-print book dealers, and I sent them all a letter.
I got responses.
The books started coming in boxes.
I bought everything.
My goal was to get a first edition in very good or better condition in dust jackets.
And I started putting them on shelves.
The books started pouring in and getting shelves.
And truthfully, I think if you're interested in what Carol does, she's an independent researcher.
She's an unpublished author.
She was an inexperienced writer at the time.
College graduate, true.
Good education, true.
I think a natural-born researcher.
But those books started pouring in, and she began to feel this.
It was kind of an irritation.
How many books are there?
Where are they?
What are the names of them?
Why isn't there any compilation?
Why can't we just get a list?
There it is.
The series started, and it ended.
And these are all the books that are written.
And there was a frustration there.
So this is the collector determining that there's a research tool that's missing.
There was nothing.
There was nothing in the library to guide me.
I started putting the books on a three-by-five card, the name of the book, and the author and the illustrator, and the date it was published, and that's how I began.
I started getting...
some interesting authors, some book dealers, like a copy of the Hudson published by William H. William H. and Company in London.
I said, I don't like that.
That can't be part of the series.
It threw me off.
So it was several years later that I thought, oh my goodness, that was part of the series.
I had since learned that there were four titles published in Great Britain, and there were four armed services editions.
13 of these books came out as special limited signed edition.
So I was trying to put the pieces together.
I knew eventually I learned there were 65 titles.
There is a song book that was published in 1942, the Psalms of the Rivers of America, and two of the titles were reprinted after Skinner's death.
They reprinted the Upper Mississippi by Walter Hall.
Revised it.
Revised and reprinted it.
and the James, two of the books that she probably had ever seen herself.
Do you mention that you're a researcher?
Maybe you can give me a little bit of biographical background.
Okay, well, I'm self-taught, but what I did was... Well, how about school in Mississippi?
Well, I have a degree in political science in Stanford University of Mississippi.
It's running again.
Okay, go ahead.
If it goes again, I'm not going to believe I need new batteries.
I just put new batteries.
I enjoyed research at the university.
Test one, two, test, test, test, test, test.
It's working, Jane.
Great, thanks.
Good.
Is it on?
Yeah.
I think that maybe researching books is a long way from doing research with rats in a laboratory, but I think that my joy of discovery and working with the unknown has been with me for a long time.
I think we become more of what we are and not less as we get older.
I sort of found my niche with this series.
As the books started accumulating on the shelves,
I started to wonder who were these men and these women who wrote and illustrated these books.
Most of the names were unknown to me.
Some of them you might know, but most of them you probably would not.
They were regional writers.
Some of them were household names, like Henry Seidel Panby, who wrote The Brand New Wine.
He wasn't a household name to me because I didn't live in that era.
But he was to me.
But he was to Gene.
I read the Saturday Review probably subscribed for 25 years.
So was Coffin, by the way.
So was Coffin.
Walter Havidhurst was a regional writer.
He spent most of his academic years at the University of Miami in Ohio.
But he was an expert on the Great Lakes.
So Skinner selected these people very carefully.
It wasn't that she...
was just looking for any writer.
She was looking for specific writers who would know their territory well, who were known to the people in, say, California.
Julian Dana wrote The Sacramento.
It was I think the third or fourth book in the series.
He had written Sutter of California, which was a book
S-U-T-T-E-R.
S-U-T-T-E-R.
Published by the Pioneer Press in California, but it was selected as the book for the centennial of the state of California.
He was a known quantity.
He was a very good writer, meticulous researcher, and Gertrude Atherton talks about him in her book, My San Francisco, a Wayward Autobiography, a Wayward Biography.
So she...
had a list of people she felt comfortable working with and selecting to write books in the series.
When I found her papers at the New York Public Library, and Jean and I were there over the Thanksgiving holiday, she had a list of about 15 or 20 people that she was considering.
Anyway, that's digressing a little from
my interest in the authors and the old strips.
I started writing letters.
I went to the library and contemporary authors, contemporary autobiography.
I had my list of 60 people.
Many of them are listed in Yale publications.
And they give a little biography and addresses.
I didn't know if they were living or dead.
It was difficult to tell from their dates of birth.
So I prepared a three-page typewritten letter figuring I had one shot.
Either they were going to throw it away or they were going to respond.
They didn't know me.
I didn't have any history.
I had never written a book before.
I had never done... Did you have it in your mind at this point that you were writing about?
No, not at all.
I was doing it simply for my own personal information.
I was trying to determine if their particular book was issued in a
signed limited edition.
At this point it seems to me you're trying to document your collection.
Right.
Basically.
I was trying to find out more about the book.
It doesn't seem to be a scholarly impulse at this point.
I wouldn't think so.
I think it was a sense of order that she wanted to get things organized, find out.
It started out, how many books are there in the series?
Well, nobody knew.
And then that led to all sorts of ideas about subsequent editions and
printings and commemorative editions and special signs, this and that.
And I have to say, at that time, I didn't see myself so much as a book collector as sort of a specialist on the Federal Writers Project, because I collected anything that they had touched.
I would get a badge from a button from a convention or just some throwaway that they had announcing it.
a book fair, something like that.
I didn't consider myself then really knowledgeable about books per se.
But Carol was relentless.
She wanted to know, what is the Rivers of America?
Where are they?
Who wrote them?
And I wrote in my letter, how did you come to write this book?
Great question.
And were you pleased with the illustrations?
Were you pleased with the final result?
Do you have a blank copy of the letter?
That I sent out?
Yeah, I think I can do that for you.

and this was in may of 1991 i don't know i probably sent six or seven letters so you've had enough for four years the collection essentially started in 80s well you got the first book in 86 the collection
Started growing rapidly.
About 87, started growing rapidly.
By 1991, you're writing letters now.
I'm very, very curious.
I'm at the library every day on my lunch hour.
This library here.
Yes, my office is directly across the street.
I'm an administrative assistant to a county commissioner.
And so every day, for about five years, I went to the library every noon, researching, looking for needles and haystacks.
and sometimes coming up with wonderful, wonderful information.
But when I wrote the letters in May, I wasn't quite sure what I was going to get.
Jane and I decided to go to New Mexico the first week in June.
One of the letters I had written was to Frank Waters.
Are you familiar with the name?
No.
He was a well-known writer, Western writer, Southwest.
lived in Taos.
He has a household name.
W-A-T-E-R-S, right?
Right.
His well-known book, The Man Who Killed the Deer, published in 1942.
Since then, he's written many others.
He wrote the book on the Colorado River.
Didn't know much about Frank Waters.
I simply wrote him.
He got one of my three pagers.
And... How did you find addresses to mail to?
In... Oh, in Gale Research.
In Gale Research.
And...
It's a marvelous, marvelous source.
If you're looking, I'm sure you'll be in there in the next publication, and they would have your address, your agent's address, and your address.
They may quote from a letter that you write in response to an encouragement.
What are you doing now?
What are you working on now?
A work in progress?
And they'll put it in their next publication.
So be careful what you say.
I always do.
Anyway, Jean and I were going to Taos.
It was a four-day weekend.
We had never been to New Mexico.
And we're sitting at this little inn, a prep it inn in Taos.
It's the very same as maybe the Taos Inn.
And he said, you know, Frank Waters lives in town here.
I took my book, The Colorado, just on the off chance.
Just on the off chance.
Don't tell me you're not a born collector.
But he had not responded to the letter.
So I said, well, maybe we'll give him a call.
Maybe we'll give him a call.
We will give him a call.
I remember sitting on the bed in that little hotel room.
And I told Gene, I said, I can't do it.
Will you please?
And Gene said, OK.
called and Mrs. Waters answered the telephone and she said, I guess Jean had relayed to me that the conversation went something like this.
We just got into town from Phoenix today.
We haven't even unpacked.
Can you come at four?
And gave us directions to go up to Arroyo Staco to a little house that is quite famous now since his death.
It's become more of a shrine to Frank Waters.
We arrived.
We were very gracious.
He was sitting in a chair.
He was suffering fibrosima.
He had an oxygen.
He had the oxygen in the nose sitting there in a sweater and very, very kindly spent an hour with us with this tape recorder running.
I asked if we could tape him, and he said yes.
Because he was used to that.
We didn't know that he was famous.
We never realized he was like the Hemingway of the American West.
I mean, he's like a saint.
He's a god of writing.
He's the only, how to say it, not white man in that.
because he is about 1 16th Indian or something like that.
He's the only person who was ever accepted by the Hopi.
They brought him in, the elders of the tribe explained all of their religious beliefs, which he wrote.
And that's his book there.
And it's an exposition.
Yes, it is.
Congratulations.
And the illustrations in the book are by Nikolai Fajin, who is a Russian painter.
He died, but he was...
They had a station house in Taos where samples of his work can be found.
Before we went to Frank Waters' house... You're not going to tell the story.
Yes, I love it.
It's wonderful.
I love it.
Gene is sitting on the bed in our little hotel room, and he's going, I said, what are you doing?
He said, I'm reading the book.
Oh, my God.
We're going to read the book.
We're going to see the man.
We haven't read the book.
So it was just one of those situations.
And we're looking at the illustrations and trying to finesse this incredible opportunity.
He did sign for me while we were there.
So we did talk about the illustrations, and Frank Waters got very, very upset.
He said they ruined, he said they were beautiful, beautiful illustrations that the publisher destroyed.
They didn't know how to reproduce them.
And Phaechin, of course, I've never seen an original Phaechin.
I don't think you'd get your hands on that.
But when you study Phaechin, then you find out he was also a towering figure.
It's an exquisite condition, isn't it?
It really is.
And that book came out also in an Armed Services Edition.
And looked, though the paper hasn't boxed or anything.
It's remarkable for books of that art.
Just to give you an idea of Frank Waters, Terry Tanner, who is a book dealer and a bibliographer, did a Frank Waters bibliography, which
set at all of his work.
You know, you mentioned that he had probably been interviewed many times.
I wouldn't be at all surprised if you check with the university down there.
I bet there's a terrific oral history on it.
Probably.
University of New Mexico.
Yeah, check that out.
Those oral histories are outstanding.
You know, sometimes you don't even need to do an interview with these people.
They're hundreds of pages long.
They even have his copyright certificate for the book.
which I found an error in Terry Tanner's bibliography.
He had the wrong date for the copyright.
I hated to tell him.
It's not all getting transmitted.
It's getting transmitted, it's not all getting received.
How are you getting the books all this?
We haven't mentioned how you're finding the books and for whom?
Okay, I have book dealers who specialize in the Rivers of America series.
One, my primary
supplier is Gordon Beckhorn, Hastings on Hudson.
There are several other book dealers who specialize, but I think Gordon has been my primary source.
Do you mind if I give him a call?
Oh no, please do.
He would be thrilled.
He's a scholar.
I think he used to be in the publishing business.
You might know him.
You might know of him without realizing who he is.
He is the book dealer who carried the manuscript Primary Colors.
That's great.
That he inadvertently had it in his catalog.
He's the one?
He's the one.
Great, nice going, Gordon.
He had his 15 minutes of fame in the New York Times, you know, the guy who Washington Post is the one that posted.
In fact, we take the New York Observer, which is a peach-colored New York paper, and Gordon had called me one day, and he said, I'm going to
He had ordered some books from him.
He said, I'm going to send you a copy of a newspaper article that you might find amusing.
He told me about it.
And I said, we get the New York Observer.
And I thought it was going to fall off the phone.
Nobody in Fort Lauderdale takes the New York Observer.
And I said, we do.
And they did a story on him.

Roosevelt's famous quote, one third of the nation, ill clothed, ill fed, ill housed.

divine gifts to the country, I think, on a par with the GI Bill of Rights, for instance, which, you know, what that did for this country.
